verses.verse: Dead<WH4194> flies<WH2070> make a perfumer's oil<WH8081> stink,<WH887> so a little<WH4592> foolishness<WH5531> is weightier<WH3368> than<WH4480> wisdom<WH2451> [and] honor.<WH9202>
A wise<WH2450> man's heart<WH3820> [directs him] toward the right,<WH3225> but the foolish<WH3684> man's heart<WH3820> [directs him] toward the left.<WH8040>
Even<WH1571> when<WH7945> the fool<WH5530> walks<WH1980> along the road<WH1870> his sense<WH3820> is lacking,<WH2637> and he demonstrates<WH559> to everyone<WH3605> [that] he is a fool.<WH5530>
If<WH518> the ruler's temper<WH7307> rises<WH5927> against<WH5921> you, do not abandon<WH5117> your position,<WH4725> because<WH3588> composure<WH4832> allays<WH5117> great<WH1419> offenses.<WH2399>
There<WH3426> is an evil<WH9567> I have seen<WH7200> under<WH8478> the sun,<WH8121> like an error<WH7684> which<WH7945> goes<WH3318> forth<WH3318> from the ruler<WH7989> –
folly<WH5529> is set<WH5414> in many<WH7227> exalted<WH4791> places<WH4791> while rich<WH6223> men<WH6223> sit<WH3427> in humble<WH8216> places.<WH8216>
I have seen<WH7200> slaves<WH5650> [riding] on horses<WH5483> and princes<WH8269> walking<WH1980> like slaves<WH5650> on the land.<WH776>
He who digs<WH2658> a pit<WH1475> may fall<WH5307> into it, and a serpent<WH5175> may bite<WH5391> him who breaks<WH6555> through<WH6555> a wall.<WH1447>
He who quarries<WH5265> stones<WH68> may be hurt<WH6087> by them, and he who splits<WH1234> logs<WH6086> may be endangered<WH5533> by them.

If<WH518> the axe<WH1270> is dull<WH6949> and he does not sharpen<WH7043> [its] edge,<WH6440> then he must exert<WH1396> more strength.<WH2428> Wisdom<WH2451> has the advantage<WH3504> of giving<WH3787> success.<WH3787>
If<WH518> the serpent<WH5175> bites<WH5391> before being charmed,<WH3908> there<WH369> is no<WH369> profit<WH3504> for the charmer.<WH1167> <WH3956>
Words<WH1697> from the mouth<WH6310> of a wise<WH2450> man<WH2450> are gracious,<WH2580> while the lips<WH8193> of a fool<WH3684> consume<WH1104> him;
the beginning<WH8462> of his talking<WH1697> <WH6310> is folly,<WH5531> and the end<WH319> of it is wicked<WH9567> madness.<WH1948>

Yet the fool<WH5530> multiplies<WH7235> words.<WH1697> No<WH3808> man<WH120> knows<WH3045> what<WH4100> will happen,<WH1961> and who<WH4310> can tell<WH5046> him what<WH834> will come<WH1961> after<WH4480> <WH310> him?
The toil<WH5999> of a fool<WH3684> [so] wearies<WH3021> him that he does not [even] know<WH3045> how to go<WH1980> to a city.<WH5892>
Woe<WH337> to you, O land,<WH776> whose<WH7945> king<WH4428> is a lad<WH5288> and whose princes<WH8269> feast<WH398> in the morning.<WH1242>

Blessed<WH835> are you, O land,<WH776> whose<WH7945> king<WH4428> is of nobility<WH1121> <WH2715> and whose princes<WH8269> eat<WH398> at the appropriate time<WH6256> – for strength,<WH1369> and not for drunkenness.<WH8358>
Through indolence<WH6103> the rafters<WH4746> sag,<WH4355> and through slackness<WH8220> <WH3027> the house<WH1004> leaks.<WH1811>
[Men] prepare<WH6213> a meal<WH3899> for enjoyment,<WH7814> and wine<WH3196> makes<WH8055> life<WH9132> merry,<WH8055> and money<WH3701> is the answer<WH6030> to everything.<WH3605>

Furthermore,<WH1571> in your bedchamber<WH4093> do not curse<WH7043> a king,<WH4428> and in your sleeping<WH4904> rooms<WH2315> do not curse<WH7043> a rich<WH6223> man,<WH6223> for a bird<WH5775> of the heavens<WH8064> will carry<WH1980> the sound,<WH6963> and the winged<WH3671> creature will make<WH5046> the matter<WH1697> known.<WH5046>
